newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends down on RBI, SBI dlr purchases.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends down on RBI, SBI dlr purchases.

text.p: The rupee closed Friday at 35.7650/7700 against the dollar on sustained purchases by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), the central bank, and the State Bank of India (SBI), the largest commercial bank, dealers said.
The spot rupee opened at 35.745/755 and hardly moved until after noon when SBI's dollar demand hit the market, they said. Its sustained purchases pushed down the rupee to 35.77 level.
"He (SBI) was buying towards late evening," said a dealer.
"People will be watching out if his demands have been met. So I think 35.75 level should hold on Monday," the dealer said.
The RBI bought June, August and September delivery dollars in the forwards section, trying to push up forward premiums from the lows they had touched in recent weeks, dealers said.
"I think what is more important is the RBI is in the market and has been bidding higher each time," said a dealer.
RBI's outright forward purchases helped push the six months annualised premium to 4.47 percent from the previous close of 4.36 percent, dealers said.

"A sharp drop in forward premiums is more worrisome for exporters rather than the 10 paise appreciation in the spot rate," N.S. Paramasivam, vice president (forex) at Essar Group of firms said on Friday, referring to the rupee's recent rise to 35.75 level from 35.80 level.
"The rupee could test further higher levels - even 35.65," he said.
